title: what caring prince harry said
story: NewsWhat caring Prince Harry said to "nervous" Meghan Markle on Buckingham Palace balcony to calm her nervesLip-reading expert reveals what was said between the royals during their balcony appearance for Trooping the Colour&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMirror21:40, 9 JUN 2018Updated23:27, 9 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA lip-reading expert has revealed what caring Prince Harry said to nervous Meghan Markle on the Buckingham Palace balcony in a bid to calm her nerves. There were huge cheers as the newlyweds joined other royals in front of an excited crowd for Trooping the Colour today, but in a whisper to her husband the former actress admitted to suffering from nerves, MirrorOnline can reveal. To the general public at large, the Duchess of Sussex looked comfortable and at ease alongside Harry as she waited to curtsy to the Queen in front of the huge crowd gathered on the Mall. However it now appears she needed some reassurance from those stood around her.  Meghan was making her debut on the palace balcony to mark the Queen’s birthday celebrations just three weeks after the royal wedding in Windsor. She stood next to Harry but slightly behind future Queen Kate Middleton who chatted to Camilla as they waited for Her Majesty to arrive. According to a lipreader, at one point Harry wipes his mouth as he turns to talk to Meghan and asks her simply: Okay? His wife replies: Yeah, are you? Harry replies simply: Yeah. After asking each other if they were “okay”, Meghan also admitted to Harry that she was “nervous!” Harry replies Yes and then smiles before saying okay?    In further snippets of conversation spotted as they turned towards the camera, Harry appears to say: “Errr. When you get into it I'll tell you more later.” Seconds later, he adds: “Then there's the flypast and then we all look up to the sky.” Meghan further responds with “alright” a couple of times while continuing to smile at the thousands of people on the grounds outside Buckingham Palace. After the Queen arrived and took her place front and centre, Meghan could be seen smiling brightly over her shoulder throughout the rest of the gathering. It has been a whirlwind few weeks for the young royals, with Meghan walking down the aisle to wed Harry after a series of public family fallouts, including concerns over her father’s health. However, the former Suits star has managed to keep her nerves away from view at a series of public events - and with many more to come, she is likely to get used to the bigger displays.

title: new kama sutra edition first
story: NewsNew Kama Sutra for millennials is first to be illustrated from a female perspectiveIllustrator Victo Ngai has reportedly claimed the new edition brings a female perspective to the anicent book&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPatrick Lion15:57, 10 JUN 2018Updated17:20, 10 JUN 2018NewsThe Folio Society has released The Kama Sutra of Vatsyayana featuring illustrations from Los Angeles-based illustrator Victo Ngai (Image: The Folio Society)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt has taken almost 2000 years but the new edition of the Kama Sutra finally has a feminine touch - and the book's first female illustrator says she has brought a woman's view to the ancient Hindu sex guide. The Folio Society has released The Kama Sutra of Vatsyayana featuring illustrations from Los Angeles-based illustrator Victo Ngai. And Ngai has reportedly claimed the new edition brings a female perspective to the book after the original manuscript dating back to around 200 AD was mostly aimed at a male audience. The book has long been considered to be the bible of sex, providing advice on positions and techniques.   The new book's promo blurb reads: There have been many editions of the Kama Sutra , but none more vividly imagined as through the work of award-winning artist Victo Ngai.  Each full-colour illustration weaves an intricate story and tantalises with erotic suggestion. Ngai has also created 25 beautiful black and white interpretations of the sexual positions and these liberally illustrate the text.  A signed artist’s print portraying an amorous couple locked in the Embrace of Thighs is presented with every book.  In an interview promoting the book, Ngai told MailOnline she wanted the book to be erotic but elegant - and more than sex.  Instead of creating illustrations which are overtly sexual, I tried to walk the fine line of creating something that's tantalizing, yet thoughtful and elegant at the same time. And she realises now that she had a different take than previous versions.

title: band set for reunion at tayside music event
story: Their last gig was more than 35 years ago, but now Perth ska band The Rude Boys are tuning-up for a summer reunion.Founder members Stuart “Sparky” Campbell-Clark and Eddie Jordan will be joined by three other members of the original line-up and some new faces for a bill-topping appearance at the annual Craigie Hill Music Festival in Perth on August 25.Their enduring reputation has ensured a tranche of early bird tickets has already been snapped-up.In their heyday, spanning 1979-1982, the high-energy, seven-piece outfit toured the UK and the continent, and supported bands like Rose Royce and Bad Manners. Keyboard player Eddie went on to form Fiction Factory with fellow band members Chic Medley and Kevin Patterson, enjoying a top 10 hit with Feels Like Heaven.“The RB’s only album was Waiting for a Dog Year and as 2018 is another Year of the Dog on the Chinese calendar it seems appropriate to be getting back together,” Eddie said.Tickets cost £28.50 and admission is free for under-14s. They can be bought at the clubhouse and online from www.ticketweb.uk/event/craigie-hill-fest-craigie-hill-golf-club-tickets/8307625.

title: dundee church holds workshops to get folk into work
story: A city church is set to hold workshops in a bid to help people into work.On Fridays in July, two of the team from the Wise Group will be running the sessions at Making Dundee Home (MDH) in Dundee West Church, at the top of Roseangle.MDH runs every Friday from 11am-3pm and includes creative activity, with lunch at 1pm,A health coach and work coach with the Wise Group, which provides support into training, education and employment, will take the morning workshops.They are open to all those who use the drop-in network and others who are out of work and struggling to find the best route into training or employment.Booking isn’t necessary, and all of these sessions, together with lunch, are free of charge.

title: dundee face competition from motherwell in bid bring simon murray back to dens park
story: Dundee face competition if they are to make a move to bring striker Simon Murray back to Dens Park.Murray spent the second half of last season on loan at the Dark Blues from parent club Hibs and said he was open to a return – but only if the Edinburgh side went with another striking option.His first choice was to try to prove himself at Easter Road after an up-and- down debut campaign there.Whether he has the chance to do that is up in the air after Motherwell moved to take him to Fir Park.The Steelmen have reportedly had a bid of £50,000 turned down by Hibs for the striker as they look to add to their attack.And that’s unlikely to be the end of any interest in the 26-year-old with ’Well expected to continue their pursuit.A number of European clubs have also been keeping tabs on him since his Dundee United days.The Tangerines, too, have made advances to bring him back to Tannadice.The lure of a return to boyhood heroes Dundee on a permanent basis would be big for Murray, though whether manager Neil McCann is prepared to splash cash on the former-Arbroath man remains to be seen.In 14 games for the Dark Blues last season, Murray managed just the three goals despite some good performances. Gaffer Neil suggested Murray was just trying too hard to shine in front of his fellow-Dundee supporters and was happy with his contribution.The Dee boss is desperate to add more threat to his side and is expected to take his time before making a move for a new forward.

title: dundee family gets together to honour special womans 106th birthday
story: When you think of the year 1912 it seems like a completely different world.But in that year Ethel Lees was born in the small village of Newtyle – and just a few weeks ago, on May 23, she celebrated her 106th birthday with her large family.Ethel was raised in a two-bedroom flat in Lorimer Street, Dundee, and later in Roseangle House as one of eight girls and four boys in the Milne family.At the age of 23, Ethel married husband John at the registrar’s office which was located at the bottom of King Street.The couple had three children together Brian, Jack and Muriel.In 1963 the couple, together with son Brian, moved to Toronto, Canada, where daughter Muriel lived, and they were joined by son Jack two years later.Tragically the family were only there for four years before Ethel’s husband died at the age of 55.Ethel stayed in Canada with her daughter until 2013 when Muriel died following a lengthy illness.Although Ethel often visited Dundee she only moved back permanently to Broughty Ferry in February, where she now lives with son Brian.Although Ethel’s hearing is starting to deteriorate at the grand age of 106, she has had no major operations and her memory is second to none as she often reflects on her time playing field hockey as a goalie or her time spent travelling the world competing in Scottish Dancing competitions.She learned to drive while in Canada and only stopped when she was 92.Ethel said: “I have been very lucky to live this long and it is great to still keep in touch with my sister Ruby who will be 99 this year.“I have a great memory and could tell you stories and memories for days.”Her sons Brian and Jack said: “With a thousand stories and memories all the family wish this remarkable woman a very happy birthday and we hope she enjoyed her special day.”

title: dundee man exceeded 40mph speed limit
story: A man has had his driving licence endorsed with three penalty points and received a fine after admitting speeding.Lee Munro, 23, of Queen Street, admitted that on December 30 last year, on the A92 Arbroath-Dundee road, between Panmurefield roundabout and Balgillo Road, he drove at an average of 56.5mph when the speed limit was 40mph.Munro was fined £100.

title: dundee motorist clocked up 54mph in 30 zone
story: A motorist has been fined £300 after he admitted speeding.Matteo Casci, 56, admitted that on December 10 last year, on Drumgeith Road and Summerfield Avenue, he drove at 54mph in a 30mph speed limit.Casci, of Ballumbie Drive, also had his driving licence endorsed with five penalty points.

title: dundee people call for knitters for trauma teddy tea
story: Monifieth High School Parent Council has put out a call for knitters.The parents are organising a Trauma Teddy Tea at the school on Wednesday (June 13) as part of a teddy knitting festival.They said on their facebook page: “The programme will be run in conjunction with Children 1st, Police Scotland and Ninewells Hospital.“We will be knitting teddies to comfort and support children at traumatic times in their life.“All we ask is that you come along with your 3.25mm / 3.75mm needles and brightly coloured wool, but no mohair or fluffy wool.”Call 01382 536700 or email a.reid1@angus schools.org.uk.

title: dundee people frankensteins links to dundee in monster new edition
story: Frankenstein author Mary Shelley’s links to the city will be celebrated by a new Dundee edition of her “monster” story, which is to be published and distributed free to local children later in the year.Frankenstein: Or, The Modern Prometheus will be released online in a downloadable format, while thousands of hard copies will also be printed.Edited and introduced by Dr Daniel Cook, of Dundee University’s English department, the book will comprise the complete 1818 text of the ground-breaking science fiction novel, as well as dozens of commissioned images produced by award-winning local comics artists.“Frankenstein is one of the most influential novels ever written,” said Dr Cook. “It is studied in schools and universities across the English-speaking world, and everyone is in some way familiar with the story of the god-like scientist and his monstrous creation.”Shelley spent two years living on South Baffin Street as a teenager, from 1812-14, after her father, William Godwin, sent her to live with the wealthy jute-producing Baxter family.This spell would influence her, as she acknowledged: “It was beneath the trees of the grounds belonging to our house, or on the bleak sides of the woodless mountains near, that my true compositions, the airy flights of my imagination, were born and fostered.”The project is funded by the Art and Humanities Research Institute.

title: dundee people friends raise cash for cuddle cot in memory of aalayah
story: A group has raised £500 with a sponsored walk over the Tay Road Bridge in memory of baby Aalayah’s fundraiser .The daughter of Kayleigh and Darren Smith spent 19 weeks at home before she sadly died last October.Her parents were able to keep her at home for the 10 days leading up to her funeral thanks to a cuddle cot they were given.The couple have since been fundraising in an effort to raise money for a new cuddle cot to be donated to the hospital.Kayleigh said: “We have now reached our target to purchase one cuddle cot and we are currently raising funds towards buying a second one in memory of Aalayah.“Our last fundraising event is a disco on Saturday at Fairfield Sport and Social Club.”Anyone wishing to purchase tickets for the disco can find information on Aalayah’s fundraiser page on Facebook.

title: dundee people from a childhood in the opera to running a music studio tristans life in music
story: The genre may have changed but the music Tristan Button grew up surrounded by still has an effect on him.The 37-year-old, who realised his dream of running a studio nine years ago when he launched Dundee Music Studios, said his father was president of the Tayside Opera for many years.&#8220There was constantly people coming around the house, other people from the opera would all come around, drink some wine and sing some songs,&#8221 he said.&#8220It was mainly classical music that I was interested in when I was very very young.&#8220If there was ever any children&#8217s parts, me and my sister would get dressed up and thrown on stage, I sure to enjoy that.&#8220There was never much singing involved, it was mostly just being children running around on stage.&#8221Tristan said he started playing the cornet when he was four or five, and then moved on to the baritone horn while he was a student at Grange Primary School in Monifieth.&#8220But I always wanted to play the trombone and they didn&#8217t have one in the music department, but eventually the must have got a bit of extra cash and got a trombone so I started playing the trombone,&#8221 he said.&#8220And I did that right thought to near the end of high school.&#8221While he trained and began working as an engineer, he started DJing electronic and hip-hop music, later moving into scratch DJing.&#8220Some of my friends had a band and my best friend had just been asked to be the drummer so he asked if I wanted to come along and do some scratching on top of the music,&#8221 he said.After a few weeks, Tristan asked if they were ok with him bringing along his synthesizers and the band kicked off from there.&#8220It was great, we had a great time doing that and the band was together for about 12 years.&#8221Spending most of his spare time being involved in music and going into so many studios, Tristan said he always had it in the back of his mind that he one day wanted to run his one of his own.He took a few business classes and looked into what it would involve, but the timing didn&#8217t feel quite right.Then in 2007, both his parents passed away within two months of each other.&#8220It kind of just turned my life on it&#8217s head,&#8221 he said.He quit his job and spent six months travelling around Australia with his future wife, before coming back to DundeeThen in 2009 he was told that a charity studio run by his friend&#8217s dad near the Marketgait was up for sale, and Tristan decided to take the chance.&#8220It was quite a big thing for me, a bit of a massive thing for me actually but at that point in my life it was a risk I was willing to take,&#8221 he said.He launched the studio, a band booked one of his rooms full time and the business began to slowly grow, but it wasn&#8217t until about a year and a half after opening that it began to turn profitable.&#8220I remember six months into it being really really worried about things, that I might not be able to keep running,&#8221 he said.&#8220But I persevered with it and it&#8217s worked out.&#8220I&#8217m never going to be a millionaire from running the studio but it&#8217s more of a lifestyle job. I get to spend an awful lot of time with my kids which I&#8217m quite grateful for.&#8221There is still a lot of hard work which goes into the studio, with Tristan and Harris, one of the studio&#8217s staff, staying up until 5am one recent weekend to prepare it for the launch of the Dundee Music Academy, but it&#8217s paying off.The Academy is Tristan&#8217s next big project and he wants to encourage more people to start playing music.&#8220We&#8217ve got big plans for the music academy and high hopes for it,&#8221 he said.

title: dundee people pictures dundee youngsters take steps to show off their urban moves
story: Hundreds of little groovers had the chance to show their moves in the city’s biggest dance festival.The festival, which took place at the Gardyne Theatre, saw approximately 600 children showing off what they have learned in their Urban Moves dance classes run by Leisure and Culture Dundee.Running over three days, the dance festival invited different Urban Moves classes to show off their skills to friends, family and other dance enthusiasts, ensuring all of the varying age groups got the opportunity to experience dancing on the big stage.“We have also now extended to evening classes for some of the more senior pupils from S1 upwards.“At the event all the kids were great – with so many children it could have been crazy but they were all fantastic and so keen to get up on the stage.“We work with them all year round to build up their confidence so there was no stage fright. They were all raring to go.”Alongside primary school groups, there was also the chance for the dance programme’s elite dancers from the Urban Moves Junior Company, Urban Moves Training Company and Urban Moves Dance Company to showcase their skills.Alex added: “It was great having the development companies perform each night too.“I think it definitely gave the younger children some inspiration on what they can do and they just loved sharing the stage with them.”The Dance Company was also recently involved in a promotional video for Maggie’s Penguin Parade, which kicks off this summer, and will be heavily involved with shows throughout the next few months.Alex Hare, dance manager for Leisure and Culture Dundee, said the three day event was “absolutely fantastic”.She said: “The weekend was full of incredible dancing and each and every dancer and member of the audience had an amazing time.“The weekend showcase is an annual event and really gives the kids a chance to show the skills they have learned throughout the year in their dance classes.“In partnership with Dundee City Council, Urban Moves goes into primary schools each week after school and teaches the kids new routines and help them develop new skills.The Claypotts Castle PS (P1-3) Urban Moves Junior Group.

title: dundee people trying to find after 73 years mervyns looking for family ties to dundee
story: An adopted man whose mother went into labour while in prison has appealed for information in Tayside as he now believes he has family ties to Dundee.Mervyn Miller, 73, was put up for adoption after he was born three months premature while his unmarried mother was in HM Prison Edinburgh, having been locked up in 1944 for shoplifting.Mervyn said he has lived a “lucky” life but, upon retirement, decided to trace his family history. He has uncovered ties to Dundee and is appealing to anyone who may have known his mother, whose birth certificate he has not found.He believes his mum, Irene Miller or Millar, was born in Canada but grew up and worked in Dundee. Mervyn thinks his maternal grandmother travelled to Canada while pregnant, but returned to Scotland shortly afterwards.He has found a cousin, Freda, and an uncle, Raymond, who live in Dundee, but neither has been able to shed much light on the mystery. Freda’s mum also lived in Dundee and Mervyn suspects she and his mum would have hung about together.He said: “It would be a great satisfaction to know what happened to her. We just can’t find a birth certificate. In a jute mill or other factory, everyone knows everyone so there might be someone in Dundee who knew my mother.”Irene ended up in Liverpool working as a prostitute but that is where the trail goes cold.His father is even more of a mystery, but as Mervyn is mixed-race he believes a man from Pakistan, India or Sri Lanka came to Dundee for the jute industry.Born with spina bifida, Mervyn spent much of his childhood at a children’s centre in Edinburgh. Aged 18, he needed both feet amputated after a series of ulcers and fevers.

title: dundee swimming coach frank among local heroes recognised in queens honours
story: A local swimming coach, a campaigner for tolerance and a Citizens Advice worker have been recognised in the Queen’s Birthday Honours.They’re among a handful of hard-working Taysiders who received the accolades for their efforts to better their community and the world.Frank Jordan, honorary president of Menzieshill Whitehall Swimming and Water Polo Club, received a British Empire Medal (BEM) for his services to the water sports. He founded one of the club’s predecessors, Menzieshill Swimming and Water Polo Club, in the 1970s. It merged with Whitehall Amateur Swimming Club in 2003.Michael Haines, from Dundee, who established the campaign Global Acts of Unity to promote tolerance and unity among communities, received an OBE.He founded the movement following the death of his brother, David, from Perth, who was killed by the Islamic State group in 2014 after being captured.Rather than be angry with his brother’s killers and blame their religion or other motives for their actions, he formed GAU to break down barriers among people from different walks of life.Hilary Wiggans, an in-court adviser for Tayside at Dundee’s Citizens Advice Bureau, has received an MBE.Arbroath resident Catherine Ferrie, a former senior lecturer and head of school and director of curriculum at Dundee and Angus College, has also been presented with an MBE.Her fellow Red Lichtie, Alexander Scott – honorary president of the Angus, Fife and Perthshire division of the Royal British Legion – received a BEM for his services to ex-service personnel.Four Perth and Kinross residents have also been given awards from the Queen, who marks her official birthday today.They include Dr William Jardine, former chief executive of Scottish Natural Heritage, who has been presented with an OBE for services to the environment, and Dundee University’s Professor Robert Steele, pictured left, who received a DBE for services to public healthAnne Pack, of the James Hutton Institute, was awarded a BEM for services to agricultural research, Scottish culture and charity, and Frederick Young, of Kinross, was given an MBE for services to education in Scotland.

title: dundee teen krystie wins hair competition
story: Trainee Dundee hairstylist Krystie Caithness, 24, won a trophy at the UK Wella Professionals Xposure hair competition in London.Krystie, who works at McIntyres Salons on Union Street, cut, coloured and styled hair on model Abbi Scoular, 18, from Glasgow, before presenting her look to a panel of independent judges at Wella’s London World Studio.Krystie had won through from the regional heats in Glasgow earlier this year and was competing against 35 finalists from across the UK.As well as her trophy, she won a money-can’t-buy mentoring programme and £500 of Wella Education vouchers.

title: dundee united step up keeper search as mehmet begins recovery from knee injury
story: Dundee United have stepped up their search for a new goalkeeper as Deniz Mehmet begins his recovery from a knee injury.The London-born Turkish youth international injured himself in the aftermath of Scott McDonald’s play-off equaliser against Dunfermline on May 4.A month on and Deniz has finally going under the knife to sort the problem after swelling delayed the operation.The 25-year-old had travelled to London for the op last week only to be told he would have to wait a bit longer.That wait is over as he underwent surgery yesterday to begin the long road to recovery.Deniz tweeted today to say the operation &#8220went well&#8221 and hopes to be &#8220back not long after the start of the season ahead&#8221.&mdash Deniz Doğan Mehmet (@Deniz_Mehmet1) June 6, 2018His recovery is expected to take some time and United don’t plan to have him available for the first few months of the season.With only 18-year-old goalie Josh Donaldson on the books, the Tangerines are on the look-out for a new man between the sticks, even if just for the first half of the campaign.Aberdeen’s Danny Rogers has already been named as a possible incomer on loan to fill the gap.The New York-born Irish U/21 international has spent three seasons on loan in the Championship with Dumbarton and Falkirk and knows the division.&nbsp

title: dundee united takeover no news is good news
story: Dundee United associate director Stuart Campbell, who represents fans’ group ArabTRUST on the club board, insists no news over the potential takeover at Tannadice is good news.In a blog post he said: “Since Mike Martin was appointed chairman we’ve seen the implementation of the widely reported ‘root &amp branch’ review of everything that happens at the club.“While we expect to see many more changes reported over the next few months, changes have already been made in finance, recruitment, youth and commercial.“The chairman, directors and staff at Tannadice have been putting in long hours to bring about the changes needed that will give the club the best chance of delivering the promotion to the Premiership and the financial stability we all want.“I’m not evading the ‘elephant in the room’ but really can’t answer any of the questions many of us have on the reported potential takeover/ investment in the club.“ArabTRUST are taking the view at this stage that a lack of information is a positive sign that any negotiations are taking place in a business-like manner and when it’s possible the club will bring us all up to date with any developments.“Too many times in the past we’ve seen gossip drip fed into the media on all sorts of issues where ultimately everyone has been left frustrated and disappointed.“We must also remember any discussions of this nature will be private discussions between shareholders and potential other parties.”

title: ex dundee man etxabeguren one of two new defensive targets for dundee united
story: Dundee United’s search for new centre-backs continues apace as former Dundee defender Julen Etxabeguren and ex-Tannadice man Callum Morris have been added to their list of targets.Both are free agents, though, the Tangerines face a battle to land either signature.Etxabeguren was released by the Dark Blues last month after an injury-hit year and has returned to Spain.Whether he can be enticed back to Scotland remains to be seen, although, he did enjoy his time in Dundee.Morris, meanwhile, told Dunfermline he was leaving them to return to England but a move back to former club United might be enough for him to shelve those plans.The 28-year-old played 45 times for Jackie McNamara at Tannadice over two seasons but, like Etxabeguren, has a history of injuries.He did play 40 games last season for the Pars, however.Also on the list is former Partick man Frederic Frans.The Belgian centre-back is wanted by his former club also, as well as fellow-Championship side Ross County.Meanwhile, United have announced their first pre-season friendly.Csaba Laszlo’s men will head to Brechin City on Tuesday, July 3, kick-off 7.45pm.That sees both city clubs heading to Glebe Park in pre-season because it’s the only grass pitch in the area, apart from Arbroath.n Former Dundee United favourite Nadir Ciftci is leaving Celtic at the end of this month.Motherwell are favourites to sign the man they had on loan last season.

title: full scale search for husky levi ends when he turns up in dundee pub
story: A thirsty dog was almost left feeling ruff – after ditching his owner and dashing off to the pub.Husky Levi slipped his harness outside a shop on Perth Road while his owner Carly Stevenson was inside – sparking a huge search operation lasting several hours.But the pet pooch was found three hours later enjoying the company of regulars at the Taybridge Bar.Carly had left Levi tied up outside a newsagent with Ollie, a Staffie, when the drama unfolded.The 29-year-old said: “It must have been around 8pm on Wednesday.“We were on our way to the park and I nipped into the shop.“It’s a regular trip and the dogs have been tied up countless times outside the store. When I came out of the shop Ollie was still there but Levi was gone.“Ollie started going towards the park so we started looking there. As Levi had broken out his harness, his name tag had come away as well.”The search for Levi, who will be two next month, stretched across the city with police officers even keeping an eye out for the dog.Carly said: “Given he is a husky and they have bounds of energy, we knew he could be anywhere.“I put a post up on social media and had family in Broughty Ferry looking for him too. I was obviously extremely worried about what had happened to him.“Two police officers had kindly joined in the search as well.”When Carly received a call from the Scottish SPCA she thought the worst had happened – only to discover Levi had simply befriended some folk having a cigarette outside the pub.She insisted Levi wasn’t in the doghouse for his antics, saying she was simply happy to have him back.She added: “When the call came in they told me, ‘he’s been traced safe and well in the pub’.“I couldn’t believe it as he had been missing from around 8pm until around 11pm.“We’d been searching all over the place and he was just across the road – in the pub of all places.”Kelsie Boland, 21, assistant manager at the bar, said its newest customer had stayed off the booze during his visit.She said: “We knew he was just a pup.“We gave him some food and he was really well behaved and got on well with the staff and the punters.“When Carly came in she was obviously upset but delighted to get him back.”

title: get outside and enjoy these wonderful walks in dundee
story: Dundonians looking to explore the city and get healthy at the same time are being urged to take advantage of walking trails which are right on their doorstep.Details of a range of routes – all of which can be found in Dundee neighbourhoods – have been made available by Dundee City Council.And with the fine weather expected to continue into next week, neighbourhood services convener Kevin Cordell is reminding residents of the benefits.Ranging from 15 minutes to one-hour, the strolls take in the city streets and landmarks, with the council website offering interesting historical facts about the areas.So whether it’s bird life or historical battles that take people’s fancy, Dundee has a lot to offer walkers.In Strathmartine, the 20-minute Dragons Walk takes in view of the Sidlaws while passing the former Baldragon Academy School site. In the Maryfield ward, people looking to get in their 10,000 steps for the day can tackle the city centre to Dudhope Park walk. While on the move, walkers can view Dudhope Castle, which served as a barracks during the First and Second World Wars.Anyone wanting to build up their stamina for this year’s Kiltwalk could tackle the West End Wander.The 3.4-mile route is likely to take just over an hour while passing the Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Magdalen Green.Residents within the Coldside ward have an array of walks right on their doorstep, including the 35-minute Law Crescent walk. The walk starts at the supposed site of King Alpin’s battle between the Picts and Scots.Starting off at Kings Cross Hospital, the route goes around the foot of the law before passing near to St John’s High School.Historic castles feature on the East End Douglas Circuit.The one hour and 20 minute trek starts outside Douglas Library on Balmoral Avenue while taking in Claypotts Castle.And what could be better than a walk on the beach? The Sandy Beach walk starts at Broughty Castle and takes in more than three miles of picturesque scenery.To let off some steam, head for the Old Railway Stroll in Lochee. The 20-minute jaunt follows a path that used to form part of the Dundee to Newtyle railway line. Starting outside Lochee Library the first point of interest is the red stone public baths and library which were paid for the by the mill-owning Cox Family.Mr Cordell said: “The council is committed to healthy and sustainable forms of transport and walking is one of the simplest and best ways of getting around. Walking is a great way to stay fit and healthy and these routes help people to get into shape, but they’re also an excellent way to get out and about in our communities, meet neighbours and it’s free.”For full details on the walks, visit www.dundeecity.gov.uk/outdoor-access-in-dundee/health-walks-ward-and-grade.

title: jack hamilton signing a great bit of business says derek soutar
story: Signing 24-year-old Jack Hamilton is “a great piece of business” according to a man who knows a thing or two about keeping goal for Dundee.Derek ‘Soapy’ Soutar had two spells at Dens Park, totalling eight years, and has seen first-hand how good Hamilton can be.After Soutar suffered an injury in his time at Forfar back in 2012, a young keeper by the name of Hamilton came in on emergency loan to cover at the age of 18.Watching his progress since, Soutar was delighted to see him arrive at Dundee.Soutar said: “I was very surprised Hearts let him go.“He came in on loan at Forfar when he was just 18. He was a great size, very athletic and a really good shot-stopper, great at one-on-ones and his distribution was excellent, too.“With Jon McLaughlin leaving I thought it would be the ideal chance for Craig Levein to put Jack in for pre-season.“He’s moved on, though, and Dundee have a great signing.“I worked with Jack, he’s a great lad and really down to earth personality.“I think it’s a great bit of business by Neil McCann.“He’s a good age with plenty of experience as well at Hearts and all the different levels with Scotland.“It’s a massive signing for Dundee – he could be there for years to come.“He will have to bide his time, though, because Elliott Parish did really well at the end of last season after Scott Bain left.“Every goalie is going to have times when it’s not going for you but Elliott got through that and didn’t do a lot wrong. He’ll take some shifting for Jack.“What it will do is push Parish to be as good as he can because he knows Jack will be breathing down his neck.”After a steady first season at the now renamed Kilmac Stadium, Parish will feel he’s the current No 1 at the club but the arrival of another senior goalie can spur both to excel – and that’s good news for the Dark Blues.Hamilton has represented Scotland at every age level from U/15 to U/21 and was called up to a squad by Gordon Strachan in May 2016.He didn’t get a first senior cap but Soutar reckons he can push his way back into the national set-up by impressing for Dundee.He added: “Not so long ago he was in the Scotland squad.“He maybe lost a bit of confidence last season at Hearts and being on the bench.“He’s very professional and will push himself to the max to make sure he’s ready for pre-season at Dundee.“He’s very level-headed, he’s not one for the big-time if you know what I mean, he’s not a flashy kind of guy.“I know the kind of level Jack can play at, I’ve worked with him and I think he could get himself back in the Scotland set-up while at Dundee.“Whatever fee was paid, he’ll definitely justify it.“Further down the line, he could even get Dundee a fee if he moves on so, for that reason, I think it’s a great piece of business.“Working with (goalkeeping coach) Rab Geddes every week, too, can only bring the best out in Jack.“A three-year deal gives him security and playing for a manager who wants him in Neil McCann will help no end.”The former Dundee and Aberdeen goalie, meanwhile, is still going strong with his Derek Soutar Goalkeeping Academy.“It’s still going really well,” he added. “That’s us had 38 goalies over seven years go on to play pro-youth and we’ve had one recently go out to the US for a scholarship.”Any budding young goalies can find out more on the academy’s Facebook page.

title: manchester united boss jose mourinho watches dundees former arsenal midfielder glen kamara amid transfer speculation
story: Jose Mourinho was watching as Dundee’s Glen Kamara picked up his fourth international cap in Finland’s friendly defeat in Romania.The 22-year-old has drawn plenty of interest in his time at the Dark Blues – Mourinho, however, was only there as a guest of Romanian agent Ioan Becali and stressed in an ad-hoc TV interview he wasn’t looking at players, just enjoying his time off.Kamara, meanwhile, despite only joining up with the Finnish national squad on Monday, played the majority of the second half in Ploiesti.The Finns, ranked 62nd in the world and not at this year’s World Cup, started the friendly match well but fell behind in the first half to Cristean Manea’s 37th-minute strike.In the second period, Kamara made his entrance after 57 minutes for Nottingham Forest’s Thomas Lam but almost immediately the team fell further behind.On 61 minutes, winger Ciprian Deac finished from close range to give the Romanians a home victory.Finland boss Markku Kanerva said: “The start was challenging but we looked good. We fought well and did not give up.“Of course, we should not be satisfied with this result but we did not have a full squad.“At the end, we got a little bit to attack more.“I had to think a little about the team when Pyry Soiri and Glen Kamara were only involved on Monday for the first time so they only played the second period.“There was little to be done in the last third. Romania defended the centre very well and, of course, it is a good team.”Finland play Belarus in Kamara’s birthplace, Tampere, on Saturday.

title: new rule all dundee united players must live within 25 miles of tannadice
story: Dundee United chairman Mike Martin has vowed the club will not continue to “reward failure” in a shake-up of the wage structure.Martin took overall charge of the club in March and is conducting an overhaul of how the club is run.He said: “We have put a new wage structure in place which is split between Championship and Premiership, ensuring players coming to the club know what they will be paid in the Championship but also know the earning opportunity once we are back in the top flight.“Linked to that, we have increased the reward element of total pay. In other words, we are going to reward success – and reward it quite handsomely.“However, we’re not going to reward failure. We have been very clear to the players still here, and those joining, that we expect success and are happy to pay for that success. We will not continue to pay for mediocrity.”Martin has also put in a place a rule that harks back to the Jim McLean days as he wants every player to be living within 25 miles of the city.He added: “What we are saying to these professionals is we want them to live in the Dundee area.“We don’t just want them to be part of the team but also part of the club and part of the community.“We have put in place a new rule that says players need to live within a 25-mile radius of Dundee and we believe that will be a major factor in creating the spirit and collegiate nature we want to implement.”

title: selfless dundee schoolgirl raises 700 by forgoing birthday gifts
story: A selfless schoolgirl has raised nearly £700 for a mental health charity after she asked friends to donate to the organisation instead of buying her gifts.Daisy Soutar turned 13 earlier this month and asked pals and family to pledge cash to the Scottish Association of Mental Health (SAMH).The generous teen has raised £670 for the charity, which provides support to those dealing with mental health issues such as depression and anxiety.Daisy, who lives in Broughty Ferry, chose to raise money for the charity after experiencing a tough period at her old school.She now attends Grove Academy and is happier.Daisy said: “I think it’s really important to talk about your mental health.“If you keep it all inside it will just build up and you’ll have way more on your mind, and that’s never good.“It’s really important to open up and tell people how you’re feeling. When I was having a hard time I would talk to my mum a lot, and my guidance teachers at school helped, too.”She added that she hoped her money would help support those in need.“I was really sad at my old school as people were saying really mean things and it would make me cry,” she said.“I know what it’s like to have issues with your mental health.”In all Daisy, who has aspirations of becoming an actor, raised £610 from her birthday cards and party alone.Another £60 has been donated through a fundraising page at justgiving/fundraising/daisy-mae-soutar.Daisy’s mum, Shona Anderson, said her daughter had made the decision to turn down gifts herself, adding: “I’m really proud of her.”Jo Anderson, director of external affairs at SAMH, was also full of praise for the generous teen.“A big thank-you to Daisy,” she said. “She is giving SAMH the best gift, helping us to create positive change for young people in Scotland.”

title: British Empire Medal recipient honoured
story: &nbspAN Inverness man has been honoured to celebrate 50 years of volunteering with the RAF Association.John Maclean (83), who was born in Inverness but now lives in Peterhead and is chairman of the association' branch in the town, has been giving up his time to help others since the end of his active service in the 1960s.He also served in a number of senior roles in the organisation, and now his efforts have been recognised after he was awarded the British Empire Medal.Mr Maclean said: "It' nice to have your hard work recognised."I took out life membership when I was leaving the air force in 1966 and soon after I started volunteering with the association."It becomes like a big family. That' the best way to explain it."The youngest person I helped was an eight-month-old baby who was having breathing problems. We helped sort out transport to and from the hospital and things like that. She has now graduated from university so it was really nice to see that."The medal is one of the highlights, but I think the friendship you get is the most important thing."His family have spoken of their pride and say the award is richly deserved. Mr Maclean' sister Marian Macdonald (75) added: "The whole family is very proud of him. He is a very quiet, unassuming person and you never hear him talking about how much he does. He just gets on with it. Our father was in the air force and was a member of the association."That' how John got involved with it in the first place."Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Casual attitude proves a winner for Fortrose cafe
story: &nbspA BLACK Isle cafe has been named Scotland' best choice for casual dining at the third Scottish Hospitality Awards.Fortrose Cafe won the north casual dining title at the awards ceremony at the Crowne Plaza Glasgow Hotel, before going on to beat the three other regional winners to the overall Scottish title.Owner Janet Gray admitted that even when she looked at the official winners photographs from the night, she found it hard to believe they had won both the local and Scottish titles."It came as a complete surprise," she said."The competition was really strong in the north finals. We&rsquore not yet four years old and just a small cafe and we were up against some quite well established opposition."Then to get the national award after that was unbelievable. We are just completely delighted."The Black Isle had another winner in Old Drynie House Bed &amp Breakfast, Kilmuir, which was named north Bed &amp Breakfast of the year.Husband and wife owner-operators Alasdair and Deirdre Mackenzie said they were thrilled to have won, especially given the high quality of the nominees."We started out a few years ago, blessed with an outstanding property," they said."We&rsquove built on that very solid foundation and very much believe that guests coming to our home are part of our family for as long as they are here."The Stables Restaurant and Grill in Fort William also claimed a national title winning both the Scottish and north restaurant of the year.Tigh na Sgiath Country House Hotel in Dulnain Bridge competed the line up of Highland winners by claiming the north hotel award.The Scottish Hospitality Awards 2018 acknowledged the success of Scotland' hospitality sector, from pubs and restaurants to festivals and family attractions, with the winners chosen by members of the general public.The black tie event, hosted by STV radio presenter Zara Janjua, attracted around 200 guests and finalists and also raised funds for charity partner, The Well Foundation.Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Council plea to ministers for money
story: &nbspCOUNCIL chiefs urgently want &pound180 million extra government funding to improve Highland roads maintained by the local authority.They are telling the UK Treasury and Scottish Government that "just to maintain the road network in its current state, where it gets no better or worse" would require &pound21.7 million annual investment "not including bridges or footways".The figures feature in a four-page plea which also begs for urgent additional funding for schools.The council' independent-led administration reminds the respective governments that, in an age of ever tighter purse strings, it has to manage 4200 miles of roads, more than 2000 bridges and culverts and 100 car parks.The plea stated: "In 2011, we had the 11th best road network in Scotland &ndash we are now seventh worst in 25th place".It argues that it has only&nbsp &pound6.4 million per year &ndash a third of the required funding &ndash available for road resurfacing.The document stated the council cannot afford to further increase the proportion of our revenue budget spent on the network while having the fourth highest debt of Scotland' 32 councils, currently standing at &pound836.7 million.It stated the 2018/19 Scottish Government grant is &pound41 million, of which &pound9.6 million is needed for three flood prevention schemes &ndash and the remaining &pound31.4 million is needed to support all other council assets.The administration highlights the fact that it has the largest number of schools &ndash 204 &ndash and 12 are currently over capacity.Asked how worthwhile the approach to the two governments was, Highland Council leader Margaret Davidson said: "We are a special case. We&rsquove got the most roads and schools and most of them in the poorest condition. That' nobody' fault, that' our geography."She expected both governments to insist that grant support has risen year on year &ndash something the council has consistently disputed.A spokeswoman for the Scottish Government said: "Highland Council has had more money this year from the Scottish Government despite UK government cuts to our budget. It will receive over &pound487 million Scottish Government funding.This is &pound17.1 million more to support services compared to last year taken together with the decision to increase their council tax by three per cent. The local government needs-based funding formula takes into account a number of factors such as rural and island communities, as well as road length and number of school pupils."A spokesman for the UK Treasury said: "We&rsquove helped make the Scottish Parliament one of the most powerful devolved bodies in the world and they have a full range of tax powers to raise funds."Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Flying the flag for equality for women
story: &nbspAN eye-catching banner made by a group of women in Inverness will take centre stage in a mass procession this weekend to celebrate the centenary of British women being given the right to vote.Members of Highland Multicultural Friends joined forces with a Merkinch craft group to create the artwork which will be carried through the streets of Edinburgh.&nbsp&nbspThe parade, which takes place on Sunday, coincides with others in London, Cardiff and Belfast involving tens of thousands of women.&nbspThe Inverness banner is one of just 100 which have been specially commissioned by 14-18 Now, the UK' arts programme for the World War I centenary, in conjunction with public art producer, Artichoke.It is intended to echo the suffrage movement, voicing women' contemporary hopes and concerns.The two groups involved in its creation were Common Threads &ndash part of Highland Multicultural Friends &ndash and Blazing Needles of Merkinch.Common Threads&nbspis an informal friendship and support group for women from different cultural backgrounds who share a common interest in handiwork ranging from embroidery and patchwork to knitting and crochet.It meets weekly at the Cameron Youth Centre in Planefield Road.Blazing Needles, formed under the now defunct&nbsp Arts in Merkinch organisation, meets weekly at the Bike Shed in Grant Street.Project co-ordinator Catherine MacNeil said the women were delighted with the completed artwork which was created with the help of a professional artist."They wanted to make it clear that they were women from the Highlands," she said."They also wanted it to show that while this is a celebration of women getting the vote there is still a long way to go."Words such as equality, diversity and compassion feature on the banner."These are things which they feel we are still working towards &ndash and not just for women," she said.The project brought together a broad range of women,&nbsp some of whom came to the Highlands from countries where equality is still a dream rather than a reality."Every woman is different," Ms MacNeil said."They all brought something different to the project."They all had their own perspective which added to the dialogue because of their own life experiences."She also felt it had enabled new links and friendships to be formed."I think the main thing they enjoyed was that it was a collaboration," she said."It was not just one group which meets regularly &ndash it was two groups coming together."They enjoyed meeting new people from the other group."They also enjoyed the opportunity to work with a professional artist who helped them to develop new ideas. They found that really positive."They really liked the fact they were all able to have input in the design process right from the beginning to the final piece."The artist allocated to work with the women was Heidi Soos.Based in Inverness, the textile artist is behind Highland Fairy which specializes in creating one-off, customized, recycled vintage garments and accessories.Sunday' parades around the UK will see tens of thousands of women and girls walking&nbsp together wearing colours of either green, white or violet.The intention is that the processions will be choreographed to form a living, moving suffragette flag.Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Merkinch schools on the verge of a new era
story: &nbspTHE poorest pocket of the Highlands is a step closer to having a new school campus.Councillors are next week expected to approve plans to bring the category B listed Merkinch Primary and nursery school into the 21st century with larger premises, all-weather sports pitch and multi-use games area.It could also feature a family centre.Previous extensions will be demolished. A new extension would feature a two storey teaching block to function as a new primary school and nursery with an adjoining single-storey, double-height sports block.The council promises a "contemporary design and twin pitched roof".Planners have recommended the south planning committee approve their plans for the 142-year-old school at a meeting next Tuesday.The plans include provision for play areas, gardens and a courtyard.Existing pedestrian and vehicle access from Telford Road would remain but two new accesses would be created on Carse Road, one providing access to four disabled parking bays. Another, at the western end of the site, would lead to a new car park.An existing recreation ground to the rear of the school is widely used by the local community. As part of the development, the land would become part of the school grounds but remain available for community use outwith school hours.The area, known as the Carse playing field, is used by the Merkinch Partnership which was established in 2006 to help support and build projects focused on the environment, culture and the arts.A new car park would service the primary school and nursery while the family centre would make use of the access and parking area off Telford Road.Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: No date yet for work to start on city eyesore
story: &nbspA QUESTION mark is hanging over a start date on work to remove a fire-damaged building blighting Inverness city centre, despite previous reassurances it would be as early as this month.Since the Eastgate Hostel went up in flames in April 2013, there has been increasing frustration over a lack of visible action at the site, which remains swathed in scaffolding,Hopes were raised in March when the owners lodged a planning application to remove the scaffolding and demolish the remaining building ahead of a rebuild.At the time a spokesman said that, if approved, work would start as early as June.But it has now emerged discussions are still on-going between Highland Council officials and the owners in a bid to resolve unforeseen issues.Concerns have also been raised by the council' building conservation and environment officer that the proposed rebuild is lower than the original.Nearby businesses are fed-up at the lack of progress.Chiropodist Jim Crawford, whose practice is in Stephen' Brae, said it was "beyond belief"."If it doesn&rsquot start by the end of June, I think there are real problems and the council should take it over," he said."It has lasted far too long. There always seems to be some excuse which is holding it back."Barber Greg Dodds, of For Men Only, was also frustrated at the lack of information."It seems ridiculous," he said.City centre manager David Haas said talks with the agents were progressing "constructively" but declined to comment on a possible start date."There are a number of issues relating to permission we are working through with council officials and the agent," he said.It has emerged that the council' principal officer for building conservation and environment, Andrew Puls, has raised concerns on conservation grounds regarding the proposed rebuild.In response to the application for the proposed demolition, he states the proposed replacement building is one storey lower and would not "preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the conservation area".A statement issued by two of the site owners, Mr Ali and Mr Cheng, states that "regrettably" unforeseen issues meant the scaffolding would not now be removed in June as originally envisaged.However it also claims that "a new way forward" being investigated should ultimately lead to a much speedier rebuild of the fire damaged building as well as allowing the owners to deal with various matters which had arisen from the recent planning application.Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pilot helps jet fan take to the skies
story: &nbspA BOY with a keen fascination for planes saw his dream come true when a pilot took him on a surprise trip in a vintage jet.Inverness teenager Yusuf (14) was known to the pilots at the city airport as "the threshold lad" because he would regularly visit the edge of runway five to take photographs of aircraft.The autistic lad, who has asked for his surname not to be published, loves to watch the Jet Provost aircraft in particular and thinks of the airport threshold as his "happy place" &ndash convincing his mother, Mhairi, to take him there whenever things in life get tough.She said: "His love of aviation &ndash civil and military &ndash has been there since he was younger, but has grown over the years into his main hobby."Pilot Paul Gibbs found out about Yusuf' passion for planes after his wife got talking to Mhairi by the runway during an earlier flight for the jet. The retired training aircraft is now only usually flown for the owner himself or his friends and associates.Tracking Yusuf down through a Facebook appeal, Mr Gibbs was impressed by his enthusiasm when they finally met."He goes out in all weathers and in all seasons &ndash this boy is keen, just like I was," he said."I made contact and offered to get them airside and show them around the hangar, with particular emphasis on his favourite machine, the Jet Provost."A former Highland Airways and Flybe captain, Mr Gibbs now works on contract in China but lives near Dalcross. He had to work hard to gain the trust of the shy Yusuf, but once they entered the aeroplane hangar, he said, Yusuf "came alive"."We sat in the cockpit and I gave him a full tour of the workings of the vintage jet," he said."His knowledge continued to impress me."Mr Gibbs then offered Yusuf the chance of a lifetime, inviting him to fly with him."Knowing his anxiety issues, and very little else about his condition I didn&rsquot want to put pressure on him or cause him distress," he said. "But it was clear he was up for it, and then some!"After one failed attempt when the haar was too thick for the planned flight to take place, Yusuf finally made it into the sky on Monday."He had the chance to take the controls and flew smoothly and precisely," said Mr Gibbs."His family were watching from his &lsquohappy place&rsquo as we overflew them and broke into the circuit to land."It was a pleasure and honour to fly this special trip, and I hope he goes on to continue to develop his aviation future in whichever way it takes him."Mhairi thanked Mr Gibbs and his wife afterwards, telling them that "without kind-hearted people like you both the world would be at a complete loss."Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Stateside search for market dog answers
story: &nbspA DETERMINED local historian is hoping a letter to America may finally solve the mystery of a faithful dog that died in a catastrophic fire in Inverness in the late 19th century.Norman Newton has been delving into the poignant tale of the canine superhero that refused to leave the butcher' shop it was guarding when the inferno destroyed what is now the Victorian Market in June 1889.The story will feature in a trailblazing digital project to be launched by Highland Council at the end of this month, bringing city legends and landmarks to life &ndash but despite extensive research no one has been able to discover the dog' name.Undeterred, Mr Newton is pinning his last hopes on a Scottish-born woman now living in New York &ndash the great-granddaughter of the butcher who owned the dog."She is perhaps the last possibility for more information about the fire and the dog through family stories," said Mr Newton, of Blackwell Road, Culloden."The rational part of me says it is unlikely. But a story like that is so dramatic that surely it would have passed down through the family."Mr Newton managed to track down the woman by following clues from sources such as reports of the fire in newspapers including the Inverness Courier, plus help from the family historian at the Highland Archive Centre.Having identified the butchers A&ampD Macdonald, along with the location of the family farm in Glenmoriston, he subsequently discovered the great-granddaughter of Alexander Macdonald had married in Dundee in 2009 but was living in America."I do get a bit obsessive when it comes to researching local history," he conceded. "It takes on a life of its own."It is like being part historian and part detective. You have to follow the clues and work out what is going on."He has now written to her outlining the story and other details of her family history and is awaiting a reply.From researching the 1901 census, Mr Newton also discovered the dog' owner was a Gaelic speaker. He speculated the dog might only have responded to Gaelic commands, which would explain why it refused to leave its post when the fire broke out as the owner was not present.If no definitive answer is forthcoming from America, the public will be invited to help name the dog.The council has come up with a shortlist of potential names including Dileas, Gaelic for faithful. Other contenders are Mac, Market Molly and Market Morag.A new plaque at the Market will honour the dog which was the only loss of life in the fire described by the Inverness Courier at the time as the most destructive in 40 years, causing estimated losses of &pound12,000 and leaving families homeless.Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Ugliest buildings in Inverness to be redeveloped and castle converted
story: &nbsp&nbspA "ONCE in a generation" opportunity for Inverness has been grasped by Highland Council as it has confirmed plans to buy the ugly office blocks in Upper Bridge Street which have blighted the riverside for years.The Inverness Courier revealed exclusively last week how redevelopment of the site will form part of a bigger plan to create a major new tourist attraction at Inverness Castle once the courts transfer to the new justice centre in Longman Road next year.The local authority confirmed&nbspon Monday&nbspthat it has put together an ambitious "&pound5 million-plus" bid to buy the office blocks and the public will be consulted over what will go in their place.A deal is about to be signed with property firm Inverness Estates which currently owns the two 1960s buildings and retail outlets underneath.The sale price is commercially sensitive at the moment, but is expected to be disclosed at the end of the month.Highland Council already owns the neighbouring museum block.It has branded the project "Inverness Castle &ndash spirit of the Highlands" and it will feature information and stories about the Highlands, with the aim of inspiring people to visit other parts of the region. It will also incorporate the North tower, which has been open to the public as a viewing platform for more than a year and Inverness Museum and Art Gallery.Locals and tourists can also look forward to new galleries which will host national and international exhibitions, displays celebrating the creativity and beauty of the Highlands as well as "retail and catering" which showcase the best of what the region has to offer.&nbspA new hotel could also be created as part of the makeover.The project is to be part-funded by &pound1.5 million from the &pound15 million Scottish Government contribution to the Inverness-Highland City-Region Deal.The remainder will involve hefty borrowing by the council although it said it would benefit from the rents of the various businesses in the existing buildings.Speaking at the castle Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing, co-chairman of the steering group overseeing the castle redevelopment, said the investment would support economic growth and create a "sustainable, viable and must-see attraction to celebrate the spirit of the Highlands".He added: "It will create a once in a generation opportunity for future redevelopment for the city and the Highlands to create something of high architectural value &ndash precisely the opposite of the existing buildings."Equally thrilled council leader Margaret Davidson said: "This has been a long-held ambition."It will help us achieve our vision for this iconic site and Inverness Castle' place as part of a range of tourism assets this region has to offer."Highland planning director Stuart Black confirmed the purchase price was "over &pound5 million", adding: "We&rsquore still in final discussions with the owner but it will be agreed by the end of June and then we&rsquoll release the purchase price."He said the options for the site were to renovate, to redevelop partially &ndash perhaps by removing the upper deck &ndash or what he termed "comprehensive redevelopment".Project manager Graham Watson, of High Life Highland, said: "It' a one-off opportunity for Inverness to really look at how it see its future for Castlehill."The attraction envisaged for the castle will promote the Highlands' "creativity, wellbeing, culture, heritage and natural environment".Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Yellow peril told to look the other way
story: &nbspTRAFFIC wardens have been ordered not to slap fines on motorists in an Inverness&nbspstreet &ndash because the parking signs are invalid and council workers are too busy fixing potholes to find time to take them down.The "yellow peril" has been instructed to turn a blind eye on Greig Street until a maintenance team can get round to putting up correct signage.The move has left B&ampB owners scratching their heads wondering how they can convince their guests to ignore the signs and assure them they will not get a ticket."Surely the council can do better than that," said Acer Glen Guest House owner Stephen Bowsher."I can quite believe they&rsquore busy fixing potholes but are they really expecting me to turn around to a guest and say &lsquoI know what the signs say but that' OK, you can just ignore it? People are not going to believe it."The curious situation comes after the council performed a u-turn in September on a controversial decision to restrict parking between 8am and 6pm &ndash even on Sundays.The rules were relaxed to allow parking up to 10am and after 5pm &ndash plus all day Sunday &ndash after guest house owners complained it would damage trade at the central spot.Some B&ampBs have racked up bad reviews on Trip Advisor and other websites over the tight parking rules which force guests to get up early and wolf down breakfast so they can shift their cars by 8am to avoid a parking ticket.However, almost a whole year on and the old signs have not yet been replaced leaving guest house owners "absolutely livid" and complaining that they have to deal with grouchy guests who leave bad comments on key tourist trap websites.The council' response is to tell traffic wardens to pay no heed to the signs &ndash because it does not know long it will take to free up manpower to change them.The short-term "solution" has really got the goat of guest house owners. "I feel like taking a pen and just going around and changing the signs," said Arafeh Alashi, who runs The Quaich B&ampB on Greig Street."It would save money and time. I could nip to B&ampQ and get stickers and change the times. That would take all of 20 minutes."Mr Arafeh received a phone call from the council just over a fortnight ago "apologising and promising me that the signage was going to be installed within a week or two".He added: "I&rsquom very upset about this. I know the council is trying but they&rsquore not trying hard enough. It' one street, four signs, it' not exactly the whole of the city centre."Kenneth Mackay who owns nine-bed Melrose Villa at 35 Kenneth Street, said: "The council promised us nine months ago they were going to do this. We are absolutely fuming. People are spending a lot of money here and the council are not helping us one iota. They&rsquore destroying all attempts to reinvent the city centre with this palaver."The council said the signs cost about a tenner each but it was struggling to free up workers to put up signs as they were "extremely busy" making road repairs.A council spokeswoman said: "We are waiting for operatives to be available to change the signs."The priority is the maintenance of the roads infrastructure and they are extremely busy on this task therefore we wait for them to be made available to change the signs. When the staff are available the signs will be changed. In the meantime our enforcement team have been instructed not to enforce before 10am and after 5pm."Monday 11 Jun 2018 6:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: dons skipper shinnie says he wont change the way he plays game
story: Aberdeen captain Graeme Shinnie insists he won’t change his style next season.The Dons skipper, pictured, is enjoying his summer break before the Reds return for pre-season ahead of the Europa League qualifying campaign.Shinnie picked up 17 yellow cards for Aberdeen during the recently-concluded campaign.The 26-year-old’s season was extended after being away with Alex McLeish’s Scotland squad in South America.He made his debut off the bench against Peru and made his first start against Mexico in the Azteca Stadium last Sunday.Due to his yellow cards accumulated over the campaign Shinnie missed some key Dons matches.He was unavailable for Premiership clashes with Hibs and Celtic in February and also missed the Scottish Cup semi-final defeat to Motherwell.Despite missing out on some key fixtures Shinnie insists he won’t change his style of play for next term.The skipper sees it as his job to be Aberdeen’s ball-winner in midfield and knows that in his role yellow cards can be easily picked up.Shinnie said: “I’ll never change. Before the Rangers game at the end of last season I think I was about five without a booking.“I’ve been playing the same way, I don’t know what changed.“I’ve been doing the same things I always do and that will never change. I think the manager will back me up on that.“It’s the way I play the game and it’s the reason why I’m the captain of the club.“It’s the way I try to lead my team and drive my team on and I’ll never change that.“That’s my job in the team and it comes with consequences as well.“A bugbear of mine this season was the suspensions I’ve had in the big games is where I’ve sort of let the team down.“But it’s the area of the pitch I play in the way I play, so it comes around.“I went through period of getting harsh bookings, I think a few of them were my first tackle in nonsense areas.“It was one of them, it kept happening, but that’s the way it goes and I’m not going to change it.”

title: fans pay tribute to neale cooper in pittodrie celebration
story: Around 4,500 Aberdeen Football Club fans turned out to celebrate the life of Neale Cooper.A celebration of life was held for the Gothenburg Great at Pittodrie, with speakers telling stories and anecdotes about their experiences of working with Neale over the years.Fans gave a standing ovation to the much-loved footballer, in the celebration which ended with 220 red and white balloons being released into the sky.Supporters described the emotional event as &#8220brilliant&#8221.Jock Gardiner, one of the speakers on the night, and representing the Red Army, said: &#8220He always had a time for a chat, and his infectious personality put a smile on people’s faces.&#8220The northern lights has always been an anthem for us, and while we’ve lost a favourite son in Tattie Cooper, let us all think of him and enjoy the memories while we belt it out at future matches.&#8221

title: fans say farewell to dons hero neale in pittodrie night of laughter and tears
story: Thousands of fans and former team-mates paid tribute to Gothenburg Great Neale Cooper at an emotional Pittodrie memorial.The former footballer, who helped the Dons clinch the European Cup Winners’ Cup in 1983, passed away on May 28 after being found injured in a stairwell at a block of flats in Aberdeen.Around 4,500 fans – along with most of the Gothenburg Greats – packed the Richard Donald Stand last night as the club paid tribute to the man supporters called a “proper Aberdeen loon” and “a great man”.Applause rang out at the end of the night as 220 red and white balloons were released into the blue sky above Pittodrie, each symbolising the 220 games Cooper played for the club.Earlier in the day his friends and family paid their respects at a private funeral service, but they joined fans at Pittodrie to say goodbye to the popular player.Friends from the footballing world, including Joe Harper, Willie Miller, Craig Brown, Archie Knox and Andy Dornan, shared touching and funny stories about life with Neale, who was known as Tattie.Former Evening Express sports editor Charlie Allan also shared his memories.Son Alex Cooper, nephew Doug Blake, fan Jock Gardiner and childhood friend Paul Alexander also brought tears to the eyes of supporters with their memories of the former Airyhall Primary and Hazlehead Academy pupil.One of the fans in attendance, Iain McDonald, 70, of Bridge of Don, still has his original Gothenburg ticket from May 11 1983.He said: “It’s sad, very sad that he was the youngest and he was the first one to go. I think that says it all.“He was such a competitor. That’s what always struck you about him.“The ceremony is a brilliant way to commemorate his life. It shows his family a lot of folk are thinking about him.”After the service, fans praised the touching tribute.Duncan Smith, 46, of Heathryfold, said: “It was brilliant. Absolutely superb, and quite emotional.“He was a proper Aberdeen loon.“The Gothenburg Greats were my heroes when I was a kid.”Valerie Donald, 53, of Hardgate, said: “It was just brilliant. It was really emotional, and it was very well organised as well.“There were lots of lovely stories about him, they put a lot of thought into it.”Graham Morrice, 56, from Woodside, said: “It was a great tribute to a great man. Aberdeen thought the world of him, and he thought the world of Aberdeen.”Two fans, Patricia and Ali Anderson, travelled from Elgin to be at the ceremony.Ali said: “It was brilliant.“There’s not many people who would get that.”Patricia, who knew him, added: “It was just exactly him. That’s exactly what he was like. He was a wonderful person.”Tributes, which included football shirts, scarves and banners, as well as numerous flowers, were lined up in the ground as well as flower displays carrying the messages“Stand Free” and “RIP” Tattie.Amid the sadness were plenty of smiles as fans heard tales from the former Dons star’s life, with many speakers greeted with cheers and prolonged applause.The event also included videos of Neale, and included his recent appearance at the Gothenburg Greats night on May 11, as well as excerpts from interviews and press calls over the years.Images spanned his entire career, including his famous goal against Rangers in the 1982 Scottish Cup final, and his time as manager for Ross County.A book of condolence was set up in the lower concourse of the Richard Donald Stand for anyone who wanted to leave their thoughts and well-wishes following the ceremony.

title: organisation to help raise charity technology funds
story: Staff from the north-east branch of a building society are helping in the firm’s goal to raise £250,000 in two years for charity.Leeds Building Society is hoping to raise the money for Samaritans in order to help enhance the charity’s technology so its volunteers can move faster between phone, email and chat responses, and Aberdeen workers are playing their part in fundraising with a number of bake sales and cycling events.More than £40,000 has been raised three months into the project by colleagues and members through a number of events.Samaritans CEO Ruth Sutherland said: “We’re delighted Leeds Building Society colleagues and members voted to support our technology project.&#8220The money raised will ensure we remain relevant and accessible to people’s changing needs and help us respond quickly to anyone who is feeling overwhelmed.“It’s so inspiring to see staff and the public across the country, getting behind the partnership and that so many creative and fun-filled fundraising activities are being put on to support us.”

title: teacher recruitment change successful
story: A north-east council&#8217s revamped teacher recruitment process has led to more people opting to work in the area.Previously Moray Council’s schools were losing out on teaching staff due to a lengthy interview process which saw schools essentially competing against each other.The time this process took meant many teachers accepted jobs elsewhere.This year the newly-qualified teachers underwent just one interview and were deployed to vacancies across the area within weeks.The new process has meant that 22 newly-qualified teachers will be boosting numbers in Moray’s schools from August.In addition, many were originally from the area and had come back after university to complete their training and start their teaching career on home turf.
